unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Rise in Auto Ancillary Sector**
normalised: **Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Rise in Auto Ancillary Sector**

unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26th – Quality control lapses are increasingly impacting the auto ancillary sector, prompting calls for stricter adherence to standards. Concerns have been raised after multiple reports of faulty components leading to vehicle recalls.
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty sixth – Quality control lapses are increasingly impacting the auto ancillary sector, prompting calls for stricter adherence to standards. Concerns have been raised after multiple reports of faulty components leading to vehicle recalls.

unnormalised: The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) recently held a workshop addressing these challenges, emphasizing the need for robust internal audits and supplier quality management systems. Experts cited examples of issues ranging from substandard metal alloys to improperly calibrated sensors.
normalised: The Confederation of Indian Industry (C I I) recently held a workshop addressing these challenges, emphasizing the need for robust internal audits and supplier quality management systems. Experts cited examples of issues ranging from substandard metal alloys to improperly calibrated sensors.

unnormalised: "Just like in the film '3 Idiots', focusing on excellence, not just marks, ensures lasting quality," commented Mr. Sharma, a quality control manager at a leading auto component manufacturer based in Pune. "We need a paradigm shift towards proactive quality assurance."
normalised: "Just like in the film 'Three Idiots', focusing on excellence, not just marks, ensures lasting quality," commented Mister Sharma, a quality control manager at a leading auto component manufacturer based in Pune. "We need a paradigm shift towards proactive quality assurance."

unnormalised: The National Institute of Technology (NIT) Trichy is offering specialized training programs to upskill engineers and technicians in advanced quality control methodologies. The government is also considering incentives for companies investing in modern testing equipment and automation for quality assurance. Defect rates have seen a rise of 15% in the last quarter, potentially impacting the "Make in India" initiative. Industry analysts estimate the cost of poor quality could reach Rs. 25,000 crore annually.
